channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Fatema Mernissi, a Founder of Islamic Feminism, Dies at 75
item.description: Ms. Mernissi, a Moroccan sociologist whose work included studies of the sexual politics of Islamic scripture and a memoir of her childhood in a domestic harem, published and lectured worldwide.
item.dc:creator: MARGALIT FOX
item.media:description: Fatema Mernissi, center, in 1996 with, from left, Mahnaz Afkhami, Yasmeen Murshed and Deniz Kandiyoti.

item.title: World Briefing: Report Traces Ebola’s Spread in Liberia
item.description: The height of the epidemic in Liberia can be traced back to a single case of the disease probably introduced from Sierra Leone.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK

item.title: Venezuela’s Defeated Ruling Party Riven by Conflict and Scorn
item.description: After an overwhelming electoral defeat, the leftist movement founded by the late Hugo Chávez has turned inward to attack its own.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:description: "We're not going to surrender or hand over the revolution," President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela said after a rally Wednesday.

item.title: World Briefing: West Bank: Attackers Wound 4 Israelis
item.description: Gunmen presumed to be Palestinians fired more than 20 bullets at an Israeli car in a drive-by shooting.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: World Briefing: Canada: Cabdrivers Stage Uber Protest
item.description: John Tory, the city’s mayor, said that the city was enforcing current laws against Uber while developing additional regulations.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Azerbaijan: Activist Freed From Prison
item.description: Leyla Yunus, a human rights activist and the director of the Institute for Peace and Democracy, had been detained since July 2014.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Afghan President Receives Unexpected Welcome in Pakistan
item.description: The size of the greeting party for Ashraf Ghani’s visit was unusual for the leader of a country that has been in a war of words, if not more, for years.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND and MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, right, greeted President Ashraf Ghani of Afghanistan, left, in Rawalpindi, Pakistan, on Wednesday.

item.title: Happiness Doesn’t Bring Good Health, Study Finds
item.description: A study published on Wednesday found that “happiness and related measures of well-being do not appear to have any direct effect on mortality.”
item.dc:creator: DENISE GRADY

item.title: As U.S. and Europe Pass the Hat at Climate Talks, China Clings to Developing-Nation Status
item.description: China still considers itself a developing country for purposes of climate negotiations, even as raising funds to help poorer countries remains a hurdle for the talks.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER and CORAL DAVENPORT

item.title: For Indians, Smog and Poverty Are Higher Priorities Than Talks in Paris
item.description: Despite a range of environmental crises and health hazards, raising a vast population out of poverty remains a higher national priority in India than global warming.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Serena De Sanctis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sassoon Docks in Mumbai, near where scientists are tracking changes in water temperature.

item.title: In Beijing, a Day Off School for Smog Is No Fun for Anyone
item.description: Millions of families grappled with the unexpected closing of schools across China’s capital, which left parents searching for day care options and students facing additional homework.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ

item.title: Gunfight at Taliban Hostage Siege in Kandahar Kills Dozens
item.description: At least 37 people were killed, including children and civilian hostages, in a long siege at a commercial strip in the base’s outer ring.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and MUJIB MASHAL
item.media:description: Afghan security forces inspected the damage after clashes with Taliban militants at a police station in Kandahar, Afghanistan, on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel Holds 5 Palestinian Citizens Suspected of Supporting ISIS
item.description: Israeli officials said the suspects, from northern Israel, had acquired rifles and practiced shooting in a forest.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER and DIAA HADID

item.title: Chinese Justice System Relies on Torture, U.N. Panel Says
item.description: The United Nations Committee Against Torture said that while there has been some progress in China, there is still a long way to go toward overhauling the system.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: U.S. Is Willing to Use Attack Helicopters to Help Iraqis Fight ISIS
item.description: The United States is prepared to deploy the aircraft and advisers to help Iraqi forces in their long-running battle to retake the city of Ramadi.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: HELENE COOPER, MATTHEW ROSENBERG and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: A member of the Iraqi security forces on Monday near Ramadi, where the army has been advancing on Islamic State militants.

item.title: Thousands of Migrants Stranded in Greece as Route North Is Narrowed
item.description: For the past several weeks only Syrians, Iraqis and Afghans have been allowed into Macedonia, leaving them in a country struggling to manage.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY

item.title: Letter From India: Thomas Piketty to India’s Elite: ‘Learn From History’
item.description: On a visit to Mumbai, the economist and author hopes India’s elite can “learn from the stupid mistakes of the other elites.”
item.dc:creator: MANU JOSEPH
item.media:description: The French economist Thomas Piketty argues that billionaires should be taxed heavily as a way of dealing with a growing economic inequality that he sees as harmful for both society and the economy.

item.title: Americans Attracted to ISIS Find an ‘Echo Chamber’ on Social Media
item.description: As the White House takes on the challenge of the Islamic State, it is focusing on the online community of sympathizers in the United States, who number in the hundreds and fit no single profile.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE, MATT APUZZO and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: A collection of posts from Twitter accounts sympathetic to the Islamic State. Lions, a reference to warriors as “lions of Allah,” are a popular symbol. Some users praise the recent killings in San Bernardino, Calif., while others offer advice to prevent hacker groups like Anonymous from disabling pro-Islamic State accounts.

item.title: France Identifies 3rd Attacker at Bataclan Concert Hall
item.description: The assailant is said to have been a 23-year-old from the Strasbourg area in northeastern France who left for Syria with a group of would-be jihadists in late 2013.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER, ALISSA J. RUBIN and AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Climate Negotiators Face Hurdles on Key Issues as Deadline Looms
item.description: Lead negotiators said they were confident that a deal could still be reached, but observers said the compromises necessary to do so could weaken the deal so much as to make it nearly toothless.
item.category: United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
United States Agency for International Development
item.dc:creator: CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry delivered a speech during the United Nations conference on climate change at Le Bourget, just outside Paris, on Wednesday.
